Great stuff, very strong but yet very well balanced.  Looks dark as night, completely opaque.  Huge hop nose and also some roasted malt.  Body is huge yet balanced, tons of hops yet very flavorful and smooth.  Thats really a trick, I dont know how they managed to have so much going on yet be so balanced.  Finish is bitter and slightly dry.

Pours dark and black with a resilient, oily chocolate head. Aroma is pine, fruit and berries, chocolate. Taste is strong and complex. Strong dark fruit attack at the beginning relaxes into a bitter hoppiness with a long bittersweet  chocolate finish. Also some coffee and strong alcohol. Full bodied with moderate carbonation. I feel like this is equal parts IPA, stout and barleywine. Really nice and well-done.

In the past I enjoyed many of Stones offerings. For me Stones has stumbled a bit Belgo Old Guardian a medicinal nightmare, Emperial IPA (14th Anni) a bit of a practical joke. In short I was in fear of Stones falling. Stones 15th was a step back towards a true path. This beer has set a little as I found it a bit rough in early September. This beer was served in a Imperial Pint glass.

Ar- A mixture of darkly roasted nearly cocoa malt and coffee. This mixes well with a pungent citrus and pine resinous notes. A bit boozey but not bad. In short the beer smells like arrogance. 

Ap- The body of the beer is black. The head of the beer is thick and looks like a fizzy chocolate milk. Nice head retention is noted. Crazy thick lacing marks the beers passage from my glass. 

T- The flavor of the beer is deep bitter pine combining with darkly roasted chocolatey malt. A powerfully abrasive alcohol weaves itself around the citrus and pine notes. Full on bitter finish. Not bad but doesnt rise to the level of greatness.

P- The body of the beer is pretty full and a bit oily. The alcohol is a bit hot and abrasive at times. I do like the mouth full of hops feeling on a plus side but cannot rate higher than 2 because of astringency.

O- A bit of a mixed bag. I dig the bitter mouth full of hops. I dont really dig the whole Black IPA. Not terribad but not really great. A whole hell of alot better than Emperial IPA.

Absolutely beautiful smell of resin, citrus, pine and flowers, dark chocolate, roasted coffee.  Definitely smells like a dry hopped beer.  The appearance is like an impy stout, dark black, tan head.  Oily lacing on glass.  The flavor is dark chocolate, roasted coffee, molasses, pine, flowers, sort of the reverse of the aroma.   Medium/thick in body.  The finish is strong pine, flowers, resin.  Beautiful beer alll the way around.  really like an impy stout which was dry-hopped.

Of all the self described black IPAs I have ever had, this had to be the darkest.  The pour was pitch black an opaque, and the head atop was two finger thick, and khaki in color.  The aroma on the other hand was lot closer to a typical IPA, with citric hops.  There was a hint of the roasted malts if I inhaled deeply.  The taste was very unique, as the bitterness of the hops and coffee flavor of the malts were both immediately and distinctly detectable.  There was some butterscotch and  molasses flavor in the profile as well.  The body was creamy and on the thicker side of medium.  The overall impression this beer left me was that of a very dark coffee with cream.  The alcohol was apparent in the form of a mild burn, and a long lingering warmth.

Received in trade from the magnificent Meatloaf. This is the first beer to really surprise me in a very long time. Maybe because its the first Black IPA I have had. A huge, over the top beer! Smells of hoppy goodness, citrusy and a bit dank. There is also a strong maltiness in the smell, a hint of coffee/chocolate, but it is overpowered by the hops. Pours a very dark brown, almost black with a great medium brown head. Tastes like a great DIPA should, with the surprising stout-like characteristics. This is certainly not just an overly hoppy stout. This beer offers a little bit of everything: great hops, great dark malts and chocolatiness, and overall a very enjoyable beer.

Bottle. Black  pour with brown head. Aroma is citrus and pine hops, some roast and caramel sweetness. Flavor is good, soft and fruity at first. Then the strength if the hops and roast take over in a bitter finish.

Black color with a thick tan head on top.  Good retention yields some relatively heavy lacing.  The aroma is roasty with toasted caramel and grains and a lot of pine hops.  Light notes of tree bark, licorice, wet leaves mix in but this is definitely all about the hops.  This is bitter but perhaps not quite as sharp as expected.  The flavor adds some burnt ashy notes with a lot of pine hops, toasted caramel and bitter unsweetened chocolate.  Theres a lot of heft to this, right from the get go, so its not the easiest beer to consume.  Then again, Im not really into the Black IPAs.  Overall Stone does what they do best in providing tons of hops in a big beer but this one didnt quite do it for me.

Draft from Monster Bs. A real sipper, this brew has an inch thick dark brown head that lasts for the entire pint and laces like crazy. With a very soft and heavy body, notes of smoked meats and tobacco sneak through its well balanced hop/malt flavor.

22oz. Bottle. Jet black in color with a persistent tan head that gives it an imperial stout type look.  Nose is a nice combination of roast and hops with heavy notes of pine resin and a subtle kick of citrus.  The flavor is big and bold with a strong bitterness and some prominent roasted grain.  Piney hop flavors are noticeable and set off by notes of coffee grinds.  Feels like there is a touch of chocolate malt in the back end.  The palate is appreciably slick and oily with a lively carbonation.  Finishes with a lingering bitter hop bite accented by a hint of ash.  Feels like they succeeded in building a bigger version of the Sublimely Self-Righteous/11 Anniversary, but I cant say that bigger is always better here. This one is not bad, maybe a little over the top and not as impressive as the double dry hopped Self Righteous.

On tap at rose and crown. Muted roast on the nose. Not what I am used to from Stone, and not what I remember when having this previously....bad lines?  Black with reddish brown highlights and brown head that fades too quickly. Hops are more apparent in flavor, with some flora. Also lots of roast from the double black. Good - but not on par with other Stone offerings.

American Black Ale.  Pitch black pour with a brown head that had great retention and no lace.  Aroma had a strong roasted malt presence upfront.  French roast coffee comes to mind. A good pine hop note and alcohol balanced it out. Flavor had a good roasted quality coffee notes really jumped out.  Pine and citrus hops complemented the bitterness from the malts.   Alcohol was a subtle warming presence in the aftertaste.  Medium bodied and slightly dry on the finish.

Bottle. Moderate malt note of toasted, heavy pine for the hops, light to moderate dough and beef broth for the yeast, with background notes of tar and anise. Head is large, frothy/creamy turning rocky, light brown with good lacing and good legs and is fully lasting. Color is almost completely black. Flavor starts moderately sweet and acidic, then finishes lightly acidic and moderately bittersweet. Palate is on the fuller side of medium, oily with a carbonation between soft and lively with a moderately to heavily alcoholic finish. Not extremely complex, but boy this Black IPA is good. Bold in every aspect youd expect from Stones latest anniversary.

Poured a pitch black with a tan to choco colored head. Good lacing. Aroma of anise, chocolate, faint coffee, citrus and pine. The flavor followed, firm piney bitterness, spicey finish. Mouthfeel full and with a tingly touch. Pretty darned good beer, but pushing the limits of hoppy porter/stout and a "black ale."

Had it on tap, as well as out of the bottle. Pours pitch black with a thick dark brown head. Aroma is roasted and hoppy. The taste is floral and has slight chocolate notes. Mouthfeel is great with lingering bitterness. One of my favorites.
Bottle.Pours a perfect pitch-black woith a nose of gooey grapefruit and light coffee.  Flavor is an almost perfect balance of mocha and grapefruit/pine.  Slick mouthfeel.  Excellent.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: I look forward to Stone Anniversary every year.  I like the beers in the past few years have been brewed to drink now.  I let my bottle of 15th Anniversary cellar for three months.  Dark brown full bodied Black IPA with strong citrus hop aroma, roasted malts, a poster child for the style.  Another offering from Stone that when I drink it cant help to think how awesome is this brewery.

22oz bottle, this might be too complex for my simple palate but the hop flavors are greatly subdued with only a touch of hops the finish is roasty and bitter with a massive boozy feel coupled with the huge 3 finger head its just a bit overbearing

Honestly, other than a surprisingly pale aroma, in terms of intensity and identifiability, this is one top notch beer.  Looks and tastes more like an Imperial stout to me than an IPA.  Really really awesome.  Thick and a bit hoppy, this is really quite great. One of the best beers Ive had in awhile.

Pour is a black with a small mocha color head. Nose is of hops, and the taste is rather similar, even for a black IPA it is rather hoppy. Also has some dark fruit notes in place of the tradition light fruits, creating a rather complex taste, and very well done black IPA.
Tap. Black with huge foamy head. Mmm.... Havent had a good hoppy beer in a week. Bitter and roasty.

Bottle shared bt sonnycheeba.  Pours opaque with an average, frothy brown head, medium retention with light lacing.  Aroma is roast and dark chocolate, raisins, plums, licorice and light smoke with pines and floral hops.  Flavor is dark chocolate and roast malt with dark fruits and moderate hops and bitterness with a dry finish.  Full body, warmth, and carbonation.

Tangerine/citrus hops over an oily roasted malt. Hops evolve into heavy pine.

The appearance is bowling-ball black, creamy cardboard-brown head. Great thick lace.

The flavor is the burnt cookie malts of an Imperial stout, with the finish of a woody Imperial IPA. Dusty mocha flavoring.

The feel is slick and oily. Imperial on both ends. Really balanced but intensely so. Really good; super oily.

Pours pitch black with a fluffy mocha head. Smells roasted and of coffee and also a strong hoppy presence, a bit pine and a bit resin. Tastes incredibly roasty but also strongly bitter; something like a super hoppy imperial stout. Medium-bodied with a smooth texture and decent mouth-carbonation, Stone 15th Anniversary Escondidian Imperial Black IPA finishes with a lingering bitterness that is reminiscent of coffee.

(bottle - 22 oz) Deep black color with a frothy tan head. Lots of chocolate and coffee aromas underlie a big flowery and spicy hop note. Flavor is much the same. Nice hop blast with a subtle citrus hint before a smooth roasted malt backbone. Hops linger on and dance with the chocolate and roasted malts and leave a sweet yet bitter aftertaste. Really nice and I think it rivals the Sublimely Self Righteous.

Draft. Pours black with a tan head, good retention/lace. Aroma of coffee, cocoa, big grapefruit/pine, light toast. Taste is cocoa, resin/pine hops, roast, bitter finish. Palate is bitter, thick, lower carbonation. Definitely a big black IPA.
Poured from a keg in Dallas at the Common Table. Very nice head with a great aroma of chocolate. Finish was a little bitter which I love.
Bomber from Country Club Liquors. Nose is pine, roast, chocolate, and citrus. Black as hell with a big cinnamon colored head. Flavor is big bitterness, chocolate, and hints of coffee and pine.

Bottle pour. Not the hop-forward nose Ive come to expect from Stone, but still a good aroma.  I can appreciate where others have noted a "cabbage-like" scent, but really thats mild and it doesnt ruin the taste. As it warms, a full malty flavor, hints of chocolate, coffee.  Truly a brew to be savored over a 45-to-60 minute span.  Had this immediately after a Sublimely Self Righteous Ale for comparison sake, and have to say this is enjoyable experience for the taste, palate-feel and overall artistic impression.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2011 The brew pours dark chesnut deep brown to black in color with a decent dark caramel head that has excellent lacing. The aroma brings sweet roasted malts and chocolate with a hop profile as well blended together nicely, but subtle. The flavor is similar with sweet malt flavor and perfume like hops at the end. Just a bit of booze there too that doesnt bite.

(bottle) deep black with dark tan head. Aroma of citrus hops. Flavor is strong citrus hops. From color I would have thought thered be more roast malt flavor; it did become more apparent as beer warmed.
Angenehmer Hopfenantrunk, blumig aber hier bereits trocken. Sehr würzig und grasig, ausgewogen, gelungen. Zum Ende Citrus, zu trocken, wenig schokoladig. /11/12/12//12
Another great beer by the folks at Stone.  Not sure what qualifies as a black IPA but this beer is so damn good, Im not ashamed to display my ignorance.  Aftertaste is spectacular!

Black body with a tan foamage. marijuana smoke, grass, pine, floral very hoppy aromas. Rich smooth mouthfeel. Very nice semi-sweet chocolate flavors with pine sap, sugared and creamed up black coffee, nice hoppy, alcohol twang to finish--very good
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Pitch black with a fine moka head. Palate is oily, you can almost feel fat on your tongue. Floral, chocolate, coffee, alcohol and sugar. A very tasting and intense brew. Would have rated it higher if I had only a sample but the very low drinkability makes the overall drop.

Bomber de 660ml. Un gros merci Patrick. Cette bière est brune très foncée, la mousse est brune et elle colle aux parois du verre. Les arômes de houblon sont au sommet. Il y a une masse de chocolat qui cohabite avec le pin et le sapinage. La bouche est ronde, très ronde avec des notes de chocolat et de rhum. La fin de bouche tout en houblon est tout aussi agréable. Lalcool est bien discret. On frise la perfection. 8/10
Pours dark brown/black, with a thick 1/4" head.  Aroma of hops, caramel, yeast and kind of a light fruityness.  Taste is full bodied with a smooth, chocolately, malt taste with a good hop balance.

(Thumbs up for my friend John!)  Un mousse dense et foncée repose sur un liquide presque noir.  Une dentelle décore le verre.  Le nez est très appréciable et surtout invitant : un parfum de la pinède rencontre des malts doux avec des grains torréfiés et chocolatés.  Une fine réglisse et un alcool simmiscent dans la conversation.  Les saveurs sont attisées par la douce force des houblons et par le caractère noir des céréales maltées.  Un choc stimulant entre les grandeurs dune ipa et les profondeurs des grains foncés.  En bouche, le liquide est très bien structuré avec son corps presque plein et son pétillement juste.  La texture me plaît beaucoup : bien crémeuse et caressante.  En finale, lexcessive beauté des houblons avec la désinvolture des ténèbres.

draft. black.  dense and firm roast, astringent and brash but working with the course hop bitterness and aroma.   its a bit cheesy, very green and resinous and heavy with strong roasted malt, scorched coffee bean harshness and light cream notes.  cheeeeeeese and shit, for real.  but not as bad as fucking dasilky1 made it out to be.  wanker.

Pitch black pour into my RBSG 2010 glass. Thick, sticky dark brown had. The aroma is realy great. loads of pine and dank resin with a fairly pronounced roasty character. There is a slight touch of salty/savoury character as well. Fresh and a little bit of earthy muskiness. Its big and brash, but it certainly doesnt taste like a 10% ABV brew. Heavy bitterness though, even for the style. Slick and slightly oily, but it doesnt come across as overtly sweet either.  Warming alcohol mouthfeel and a touch of pine as well. Its got a lot of lingering bitterness and a not quite roasty dark cocoa character. Its damn solid.

Wow- I knew it would be good, but this is awesome! Pours black with a minimal head. Smells like coffee and sweet dark fruits- cherry? A little dark chocolate and some light floral elements. Mouthfeel is thicker than I expected, almost chewy. Strong presence of hops and the alcohol leaves my tongue buzzing slightly. Tastes a bit smoky too. Good shit!

Tap at the FW Saucer. Pours a very dark brown color with only a hint of dark red when put to the light. Tall foamy head, colored brown. Aroma is fairly hoppy, fresh pine and a slight touch of dark malts. Maybe a little bit of roast in this. Flavor is a fairly decent balance between hops and malts. It starts with a sharp hoppy bite that transforms into a malty roast in the middle. The finish is a mix of hop linger and sweet malts. Man I like this.

(22 oz. bottle (August 2011) from Global Beverage) Pours very dark brown with two fingers of tan head. Aroma is sweet, hoppy, caramel and roasty. Mouthfeel is smooth, more on the IPA side but lightly oily. Large, weepy rings of lacing. Flavor is sweet and roasty with fruity and citrusy hops along with notes of coffee and chocolate. Nice bitter bite finishes it.

Serving: 22 oz. bottle from State Line Liquors.  It pours jet black with a very large and dense head of dark tan foam.  The nose is herbal hops and a slightly off vegetal note. Kind of cooked cabbage like.  The flavor starts off with that off cooked cabbage note and goes straight to hot rubbing alcohol.  There is some roasted malt on the back end.  This crap is dreadful!  A total drainpour.  I can only hop this was an off bottle.

Draft Pours black with a small, creamy, beige head. The aroma is just Wow! really bad. Hits me in all the wrong places. Big-time armpit and old, stale bong water. Full-bodied and oily with soft carbonation. The flavor is bitter, burnt and acrid  gunsmoke and fresh weed. Bitter, grassy, roasty finish. Not  a bad beer overall, but I hate the smell.

On tap at "The Beer is Good." Definitely black, lots of interesting character to this one...smoke, dark sugars, but I didnt find much in the way of hops on the nose, which was kind of a bummer. The finish featured some bitterness, but this to me was more malt forward, and at 10.5% Im not surprised. A nice treat at an awesome event.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours just about black with a moderate-large brown head that lasted until nearly mid-glass and laced the glass well.  Very pleasant aroma of pine, sweet pine resin, malt, and some roast.  The flavor is malt, roast and molasses up front followed by some resinous pine with some moderate pine bitterness.  No hint at all of the 10.5% abv.  Rich and full of flavor, this beer is excellent.

Pours jet black, with a carmel head with plenty of lacing.  smells of malt with a nice hoppy aroma. as if you put an ipa and an imperial stout in the same glass.  tastes roasty with the bitter ipa feeling. some citrus with a nice roasted malt. feels dry and lasting with the malty thickness.  overall solid brew, with an interesting mix of stuff going on.

650 ml bottle

Does Stone make a bad IPA? They definitely have a handle on the emerging style known as black IPAs. This one is no exception; hitting a good price point it is an excellent beer. At 10% it is hard to call it sessionable but it does not erode the palate like some other high ABV releases. Get some while it is fresh and enjoy a true gem.

Aroma / Appearance - Inky black in nature the body hides anything within well. A cascading head develops and soon builds into a soft layer the color of faded leather. The nose contains the smell of wet asphalt which has been recently laid down. Coupled with the bright hops it snaps at the senses. Malty undertones anchor it in reality.

Flavor / Palate - Coffee, fresh tea, and bark from a young pine sapling rub on the tongue. The strong finish is sharp enough to leave a distinctive taste in the back of the throat. The battle between hops and malts provide interest with a texture that feels like dark chocolate and resin. I cant wait to see what 11-11-11 brings.

Bottle:   Holy crap thats a black beer, very dark, large deep brown head, fairly nice lacing.   I would have thought this to be a stout.   Semi-sweet roastiness, subtle yet ample sweet hoppiness.   I wanna say the Black is more pronounced than the IPA in thsi one.   Wow, after first sip I find it hard to believe its over 10%!   Feels like a regular IPA with lots of roastiness (without being acrid or ashy).   Not as juicy as their other Black IPA release, but still good.   Very smooth on the tongue.   Not as hefty as I would have liked for a Double Black IPA?   But yeah, very smooth and clean.   Great balance, for a Black IPA.   They say this is imperial, but if it is, its real subtle.   Did I mention clean?   Great work for a newly emerging style!

Bomber. Aroma of dark roasted fruits, black cherry, a hint of chocolate and citrus. Appearance is espresso black with a beautiful tan frothy head. Taste is complex. Chocolate, dark fruit, hints of coffee and citrus. Hop forward and malt dry bitter finish. This is an incredible brew and has changed my palate for the better in trying new beers. Its a fine example of how far craft beer had come and how far its going to go in the future.

Bomber.  Beautiful, black with a tan head.  Licorice, chocolate, cocoa, a touch of coffee in nose.  Taste of some grapefruit,  pine.  Its gritty but syrupy and oily.  Very balanced and well put together.  Its a great product .

On tap.  Had this one back to back with the cherry chocolate.  Very dark, pitch black appearance, decent head.  Big roasty aromas, some cocoa and a touch of anise, floral notes.  Big mouthful of roasted malts and a biting finish.  Im not sure what it was about this one, maybe I just wasnt in the mood for it.  Not my favorite anny from stone, in fact my least favorite that Ive had between 9 and 15.  Its good, but not great.

The smell of this one makes it seem like youre about to drink a porter: chocolate and coffee, a bit of toast. But then you taste it and its so much more than that, tasting first like caramel malts, but ending with a bitter grapefruit finish.

THOUGHTS: Wow. Very nice. Almost the reverse of most beers in that the hops are all up front and then the malts kick in. Hid alcohol fairly well. The hop profile was a lot like something I brewed, but the malts were so much better. Incredible balance and transition. One of the best beers Ive had this year. Simcoe had to be a big part of this one.
TECHNICAL: Bottle poured and opaque black in the glass with an average to large, light brown head that mostly diminished and left excellent lacing. The aroma had moderate roasted malt; lighter dark chocolate and coffee; heavy to nearly harsh pine hops; slightly lighter grapefruit hops; and alcohol. The initial flavor was light to moderately sweet and light to moderately bitter; while the finish was moderately sweet and moderate to heavily bitter. There were pine hops, grapefruit hops, roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, more hops, alcohol, chocolate syrup, and dark chocolate. The full body was oily and a little creamy and also sticky on the lips with fairly soft carbonation and a lightly alcoholic finish.

Bottle: Pour is dark brown/almost balck with a medium tan foamy head.
aroma is nice chocolate, black cherry fruitiness, very nice.
Hints of medium roast coffee.
Flavour is intense roasted maltiness. nice woody/floral bitterness. hints of licorice? 
Very nice. Did I say that already?
Pours an espresso color with a creamy tope colored head. Smooth mouthfeel leads to notes of roasted coffee and dark chocolate, citrus, and some green and floral notes. Well balanced and delicious.

8/22/11 stone 15.

black thick and creamy. 4/5

a is oniony, gf, roast,
mild pine, creamy, charcoal, choc.

f has mild choc, onion, gf,pine, ashy charcoal business

super rich, slick, creamy, nice. 8/4/8/4/17+

beer pours as black as night with a small brown head that dissipates quickly. strong hop presence in the nose along with the typical dark malts making their way through. my oh my is this one delicious beer. alcohol hidden well amongst the strong hop and malt flavors  its no surprise stone makes this fairly new style very well considering the amazing stouts and IPAs they already are known for.  superb beer. as it warms up the alcohol pokes through well.

22 oz bomber courtesy of my friends Brent and Elena. Pour is a murky black brown, with a one inch khaki head.  Head is quite solid and lasting.  Aroma is fresh pine along with a bit of dark chocolate sweetness, finally, some roast malt is present. Taste is massive pine hops, just gets bigger as it warms - almost gin like. Roast char malt is present as well, though this beer is about the hops.  Pretty harsh, though intentionally so, and since alcohol is well integrated and sweetness is managed it worked for me.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Porter & Sons. Thanks beerandbeyond. Black with a light brown head. Hoppy aroma of citrus, some tropical fruits notes and some subdued roastiness. Flavor has some malt with a bit of sweetness, some roastiness, a bit of chocolate and a roasty, citric, hoppy finish. Medium to full-bodied. Nice and pretty easy-drinking for its strength.

22oz bomber from Westminster Total Beverage.  Pours opaque black with a big frothy light brown head, leaving thick sheets of lace as it collapses.  Aroma on this little beast is faint, but light oak and pine mix with heavily roasted English(??) malts.  Flavor is an explosion of dry-hopped fun, with dry, spicy hops up front blending with nearly-charred malts, then fading to resinous bitterness at the tail end.  Creamy body, but just a touch slick as well.  The 10.5% doesnt hide...its quite in-your-face!

Sampled from a 22 oz brown bottle this beer poured thick, black and stout like with a large foamy dark brown head that lingered forever and left great lacing. The aroma was strong floral hops and roasty malts. The flavor was bitter with strong floral and harsh fruity hops and undertones of semi-sweet chocolate, vanilla and pepper. The finish was long and somewhat harsh with lingering vanilla and hops. Thick, full and creamy body. Interesting.

Bottle pour from Jeff, Thanks!  Eh.  Pour me the double dry hopped self righteous instead.  This beer was just ok.  A lot like their normal BIA (or whatever the heck we call them), with a touch more floral hop aroma.

22 oz bottle got for $5.99 @ a Deli in South Berwick, ME. Black with off white, full head in a snifter Aromas of pine hops, light roast. Thick sheets of lace. Medium body gives roasted bitter chocolate with Earthy piney, resinous hops. More chocolate as it warms. Oily, slick feel in the mouth. A lasting, pine hop finish. I only got a trace of ABV when it was real warm. This is a solid brew, but after one glass I had had enough. I guess I have to take a break from Black IPAs.

Bottle from Friar Tuck in Savoy, IL. Pours black with a light brown head. Aroma of citrusy hops and dark malts. Medium bodied with average carbonation. Flavor of dark roasted malts, bitter dark chocolate- countered by a citrusy and peppery bitterness. Finish has some roast astringency and some heat. The problem I have with this beer, and with many other Black IPAs, is that the roast bitterness and hop bitterness fight each other. There is a very narrow window where these two can be harmonious, and this does not fit in it.

Head was slow to emerge, and then it went over the edge.  I really felt like drinking out of a pint glass today for some reason.  Maybe its the dreary weather.  Maybe its the longing for those deep winter stouts.  What head was left was very dark almost reddish brown in color, I sipped it, and then off the table.  Mistake.  This beer is obviously very fresh, it had just appeared at the local market.  Nonetheless, color is jet black, carbonation is creamy.  Mouthfeel is light.  Smell is coffee, burnt peat, wet dog, must be the yeast... NW hops.  Complex.  Well hidden alcohol.  Taste has more charred flavor, sweetness in the form of imitation cherries, and fresh hops much like an IPA.  The hops sneak in from the back of the mouth and linger like a sonofabitch.  Aftertaste is some real exhaust, we have coffee grounds, burnt coal, dryness from the hops, and of course the palate piercing paradoxical dirty monkey out to ruin you good time.  The good news is the monkey isnt all that bananas and the taste is one that can endure.  If youre palate has a discord for high IBUs I suggest you look elsewhere.  Overall this is a fun loving beer in the way that Arrogant Bastard has made us all a fan.  Drinkability 5/5.

Draft @ Flying Saucer Raleigh. Black coloured beer with a  medium brown head and some very fine corbonation. Roasted malty and toffee hinted aroma. Full bitter creamy hinted palate. Finish is strong, roasted almost smokey bitter and herby malty to coffee touched. Long bitter light alcoholic ending. Almost overwhelmingly strong. Misses some balanced, but overall a nice taste.

Black, with a big brown head. Smells very citrusy hoppy, with a good deal of chocolate in the background. Flavor is dark chocolate, bug grapefruity hops, and coffee. Full, rich palate. Crisp, bitter finish. Enjoyed with some 85% cacao dark chocolate.

Bottle thanks to Tim, then traded by me to Jcwattsrugger and then shared by him. Pours oily black with big brown head. Nose/taste of dry cocoa, wet grass, chocolate malt and piney hops. Very smooth for the ABV. Dryish light pine dipped in cocoa finish. Medium body.

pours a very dark viscus. Almost like an imperial stout. Aroma very similar to SSR right out of the bottle. Almost no head to speak of. Rich chocolatey, malted roastey flavor, hops are subdued but present.an amazing beer well worthy of being Stones 15th anniversary brew

A nice version of this relatively new style. The hops are kicked up west coast style with lots of citrus grapefruit and pine. The malt is a little less roasty than others in this style but still working a bit in the background. The pour is a deep brown with a tan head. Medium body and easy to drink.

Strong sweet and resin hop aroma. Not much with the malt but it was cold. Black color with a small brown head. Bitter beginning with a mix of sweet malt flavors. Taste slowly fades with a medium bodied palate

A decent black IPA, nothing to be excited about. Aroma was alright. Roasted malt with plenty of green citrusy hops. Pour was a nice deep dark brown/near black with a one finger tan head. Taste was pretty good, but a little basic. The hops take center stage and dont let go. I like this because Im not a big fan of the style. Very vinous and soapy in the front. A little thin. After the swallow, the bitter citrus hops remain with not much else. There isnt enough roasted malt flavor to make this different. Decent carbonation. Typical Stone beer, which isnt a bad thing
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Pours black as night with a nice creamy tan head. Excellent lacing and head lingers for quite a while. Smells of roasted malts and some piney hops. Taste is roasted malts with slight bitter finish. This is an excellent imperial black IPA. With as high of alcohol content as it is, it doesnt seem boozy at all. Goes down easy which could be dangerous! Excellent overall.

Draught into a snifter. Pours a deep black with a full finger tannish-red head. Aroma is of obvious roasted malts, hops, and slight vinegar. Flavor is roasted malts also with a good hop backing. Theres a dark caramel and raspberry-like sweetness I get also. Lacing is medium on the glass but not to heavy.

Video review at: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rlR09otCkUs

Appearance: Jet black, 1-finger head dissipates to layering, excllent lacing

Smell: Bitter dark chocolate, citra pine, tobacco

Taste: Full body, bitter dark chocolate, coffee, pineapple, brown sugar, sweet carmel malts, mild warming, mild carbonation, drinkable

Pairings: Buttery cheese w/ fresh bread, brie, camembert

Bottle: Poured a deep pitch-black color ale with a large dark brown foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of deep roasted malt notes with lightly sweet undertones and some dominant bitter and loads of piney hops. Taste is a very nice mix between some smooth roasted malt with light lactose notes and some dry notes with some huge piney notes on top. Boyd is full with nice creamy texture and good carbonation with no apparent alcohol. Very well brewed and probably my favourite example of the style.

A fine BIPA, stronger and richer than the others Ive had.  Pours opaque but slightly brownish - not quite black, looks like a good porter.  Nice tan head with good activity and retention.  Aroma is heavy on the chocolate and roast profiles with a nice grapefruit tone and a touch of something floral.  Nice, but the taste is even better.  Starts off dark and roasted, chocolate, caramel, then the bitter piney hops come through strong, finishing dry and lingering.  Good stuff!  And its quite smooth, slightly oily and full-bodied as well.  Good beer!

Pours a deep dark brown that appears pitch black and completely opaque in the glass.  Two finger frothy beige head with great retention only slowly fading into a lasting cap/ring that leaves streaks and spots of lace behind.

Roasted malt aroma thats countered by some piny, oily hop notes.  Hints of chocolate, coffee and toast balanced by notes of pine, resinous oils and citrus fruit.

Fuller bodied than expected with a chewy mouthfeel and a blast of dry bitter hops up front that linger over the roasted malt backbone into a sweet yet dry finish.  Earthy with lots of piny resinous oily hops along with some subtle citrus.  This is countered by the roasted malt backbone that has hints of toast, chocolate, toffee, coffee.  Well balanced and easy to drink with a decently basked ABV.  Only subtle heat in the finish.

Just when you think Stone could not come out with another amazing Anniversary Beer... Stone 15th hits the market.  Delicious both in bottle and draft form enough good things cannot be said about this beer.  So good that all the draft in the surrounding area was drank up in nearly the opening weekend of its release.  I had to travel nearly an hour to find a place who still had it....and it was worth it! Smooth, Rich in flavor, Balanced, and a Great Hop taste.  10.5% Abv you would never guess it. This beer is amazing and recommend it to any IPA lover!

Draft at Dutchs.  If it were labeled a "hoppy stout," I think my rating would differ.  In my mind this is a complex imperial stout that has a strong hop pressence.  The initial aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, and some piney hops.  As it warms, the chocolate really comes out.  Bitter coffee notes stick out with a bit of vanilla.  Palate is chewey and thick.  Flavor is bitter, finishing dry.  Again, the rating would be higher if they were not calling it an ipa.

Bottle.  Black.   Not just dark.  no light passes through.   Nice amber head.  hops aroma and taste envelope this brew in spite of the solid maltiness.   Very enjoyable.  Share it with a friend or you may be done after one.

Bottle from Binnys Beverage Depot - Downtown, Chicago, October 2011. 

Black with a nice tan head. Nicely balanced, roasted malt and a lot of hops, grape and some chocolate. Smooth body and a crisp mouth feel. Good work!

Bottle.  Dark black pour, light cookie head and an aroma of light roasted dark malt and hops.  Flavor is burnt brown sugar, plenty of this creamy dark malt, peppery hops and finished slightly boozy (although not as much as I expected it to @ 10%.)  Decent beer, would probably pick up a bomber of this again.

Wow what a nose, this smells incredible. Big beautiful fresh hop aroma, gives me shivers. Nice deep brown/black color with a beautiful soft tan head. Big long dry bitter mouthful of hops. Definitely some malt in there somewhere, but Ive never had a black IPA this bitter. Everything about this beer is Imperial. Excellent.

From tap at Three Penny Taproom. Pours hazy brown with a small tan head. Aroma is roasted dark malty, caramelish, liqourice and crisp hoppy. Toasted dark malty, caramel and bitter hoppy. Herbal, bitter and dry hoppy. Bitter and dark roasted malty finish.

Thick and dark with a mocha colored head. Doesnt have a huge aroma but still presents you with a roasty-sweetness. First taste presents sweet citrus , followed by grassy barnyar, and finishes with a coffee-chocolate bitterness. Very complex and drinkable for 10.5%. Nice beer!

Aroma- hops, malts, booze, char, chocolate
Appearance- pitch black, huge creamy white head, excellent lacing
Taste- huge hops on all aspects of the mouthfeel, nice chocolate hints, sweet malts cut the alcohol burn and hop bitterness
Palate- nice creamy mouthfeel, not cloying at all
Overall- Perhaps my new favorite brew from Stone.  Im usually not a fan of Black IPAs but this is a gem.  The sweet/bitter dichotomy of this beer is unlike anything Ive experienced before.  Well done Stone!
Dark black in color, clear with a thin head.  Dark chocolate and hops aroma. Great flavor with hops and dark malt.  This was a super beer.

Pours a dark opaque oily black with a tall creamy brown head. The head looks alot like you are looking at a thick chocolate milkshake. In the glass the beer looks like a solid imperial stout, but you get a good bit of pine hops aroma along with some anise. The beer has a thick texture and again though it looks like a stout you get a good pine resin hops flavor initially. The flavor becomes more of a dark chocolate and anise flavor in the middle. The finish remains strong with some of the dark chocolate flavor and a more prominate return of the pine hops bitterness for a good long lasting finish. The alcohol was hidden pretty well in this one. More bitterness from the hops rather than an alcohol burn. There was a good amount of clingy lacing throughout the glass. Stone hit a home run with this one. Hope they continue to make this, perhaps as a seasonal

Bomber, pours jet black w/ heavily-laced clay-colored head, lots of oily cascade on head, aroma of resiny piney hops and light roast, huge hop flavor throughout that lingers long into the finish, very smooth and delicious

Draft. Pours near black with a beige head. Big piney hoppy aroma with citrus and lightly roasted malts. The flavor brings big and bitter hops, with pine, citrus, and marijuna. Some roasted malts as well. Good stuff.
Citrus hops aroma on this black pour with an amber hue.  Very hoppy yet with a subtle sweetness.  Dry and bitter finish, very well done.

Very dark espresso with brown head.  Pine and citrus in nose, but, whats this?...Bacon?  Garlic?  Yeah....pretty sure this isnt supposed to be a rauch black IPA...  Medium body, good carbonation.  Im not really sure what defect could lead to these flavors, but I dont like it.  drain pour.

Dark black with a big long lasting brown head. Aroma and flavor of resinous hops and roasted malts. Taste is medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, thick feel, average carbonation. Finish is hoppy and very warming.

Its a well made beer no doubt, but did it have to be 10.5%? The alcohol burn is a bit unpleasant on this one,  coming close to ruining an otherwise very well made beer. Lovely soft nose of chocolate malts and citrus pine. Theres even a little grass. Decent body and there is a bit going on - chocolate, a tiny bit of roast and some gooey caramel, finished with a bracing bitter citrus finish. Very in your face and confrontational. This could be a world class example of a burgeoning style, but its instead a very solid, overly alcoholic beer.

This is a fantastic beer.  The roasty malts give a richness, but the hops have a piercing bite that turns it into fresh chocolate, anise, and pine.   The sensations in the mouth are incredible and change from moment to moment, and keep changing and shifting as the irresistible sips keep piling up minute to minute:  mild sweetness and richness gets upturned by a sourness, and then a piney hop bitterness starts a relentless campaign to invade and occupy every diverse dimension of the palate - - tongue, cheeks, even glottus - - various dimensions of the oral cavity all start clocking in like AP & UPI teletypes after some rare spectacle - - taste buds and oral nerves you never realized you had before flashing like Vegas neon, croaking like lit-up lily-pad frogs by nuclear plants, whole oral flavor networks swaying, and careening like decks of creaking plankwood on ancient war galleons.   You dont want this to end.    Thankfully, for physical constitution, I am only in the possession of this one bottle, and I cant remember where I got it.   But I will be Googling about it again real soon, and then buying a plane ticket to where I can get it again.

Bottle. Pours a pitch black color with a tan head. Aroma is nice and hoppy with lots of grapefruit, citrus, some pine, sweeter citrus fruits like orange and tangerine, which is balanced out by roasted malt, liqourice, chocolate and coffee notes. Flavor is insanely well blended between hoppy and stouty flavors! I get lots of the grapefruit, pine, resin, citrus, orange and tangerine along with the stouty flavors of roasted malt, chocolate, cofee and liqourice. The body is full with a dry mouthfeel. Overall an AMAZING Black IPA, probably the best ive had!

Pours thick inky black with a medium-small tan head, very fine clinging lacing. Big pine resin aroma with chocolate, oak, and toast. Medium body, very dry, medium carbonation. Makes a tiny nod to sweetness up front, then hits with a barrage of thick, luscious bitterness that goes on and on. What a ride it is!

Black,lasting brown head.Great nose of dark fruit/malt,citrus,brown sugar. Roasty profile, medium alcohol heat,citrus hints. Medium bitter finish is  from roast & alcohol harshness, not hops.Not a good example of the style at all?

Bottl.  Thanks to Ratebeer for reprinting the description as it is too small to read on the bottle,.  Great looking beer; black with a thick brown head. Big brown licorice hop nose. Black licorice hopped stout. Strong bitterness. Bg bitter licorice alcohol note.
Soy sauce, leather, pine, leaves and citrus are all featured here.  Really like the aroma on this one.  Complex and excellent.

Black with brown head and lace.  Dark chocolate roasted coffee dark fruity piney hop aroma.  Rich dark chocolate espresso bean with fruity fig and raisin and fruity piney and orange hop medium bitter finish.  Almost like those chocolate covered orange candies.  Rich and complex and tasty.  An excellent hoppy imperial porter.

750ml bottle poured into snifter. Dark chocolate color with a brown bubbly head. Aroma has hints of chocolate, malt and hops. Flavor is a little dry with mostly the chocolate playing a nice part on the back end. It didnt blow me away but its still a good solid beer.
Bottled.  Pours dark with cream colored head.  Lacing.  Earthy soil and floral aromas at first.  Malts and chocolates to taste.  Pretty good.

Bomber. Pours black with a small tan head. Aroma is citrusy hops, pine, some chocolatey sweetness. Its quite bitter upon first sip, but melds into a more malty aftertaste. The piney/charred taste lasts throughout and in a way almost reminds me of some scotches. Its thick and almost a little chewy. You dont really taste the alcohol but it does warm you up pretty quickly. Not amazing but a decent brew.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Nonic Imperial Pint.

Appearance: Pitch black with thick, foamy, root beer float head that leaves intricate lacing webs.

Aroma: Citrus, pine, roses, chocolate and charbroiled meat.

Taste: Perfect integration of chocolatey roasted malts and citrusy hops. Elements of char, coffee and pine enhance the experience. Finish is bitter and spicy, with both a hop bite and a roasted malt bite. Becomes somewhat fruity as it warms.

Palate: Exceedingly smooth and creamy with a massive warming sensation. Moderately low carbonation, fairly dry finish.

Overall: Besides for the warming sensation, I cant tell that this is anywhere near 11% abv. Unbelievably smooth and tasty; the best American Black Ale / Black IPA / yada-yada I have had. Of course, one could argue that this is really a hoppy, citrusy Imperial Stout.

A foamy brown head, solid black body, and a nice aroma mostly with hoppy pine and resin with a bit of roasted coffee.  The taste is more balanced between the hops and roasted malt, and both flavors stay on to the finish.  A smooth body thats not too heavy.

Pours a black color with a brown head. Aroma is chocolate with some curtis his and some roasted malts. Nice thick mouth feel with curtis hours up front and chocolate and roasted malts on the finish. Nice better finish.
Pours black with a thin mocha receding head. Notes of chocolate, thick hop resins, grapefruit, alcohol. Full bodied with lively carbonation. Very nice, quite strong.

22oz into snifter...pours almost black with a tan head...Tastes not so good to me, I was really excited about this one but it is not that good. Tastes very bitter from the hops and from something else I get more bitter. When it warmed up a little all I could taste was alcohol. Just not impressed, was hoping for a stronger sublimely self righteous or something, but this isnt it.

Bomber from Sams, Durham. Big oily pour is not really what Id expected from something with "IPA" in its handle. Super potent nose hangs there like a fog. Body is a bit too heavy and slick, and the overall character of the brew is starting to seem consistent. In terms of flavors, the hops get more or less lost in the smoked meat and char and molasses (not to mention hints of anise), making this brew more like Labyrinth black ale than a black IPA to me. So stylistic kvelling aside, is it aight? Yeah but unlike previous Stone anny ales, I wont be looking to stock up. (Come back Emperial IPA!)

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2011 Bomber from Capones.  Pours deep black with 2-finger brown head.  This one is thick, with a huge plato.  Nose is huge resiny piney, with notes of chocolate malt, pineapple, tangerine, black pepper.  Tastes of chocolate malt, very charred and somewhat rauchy, with a huge resiny sticky IBU-laden hop load.  This is a black IPA on steroids, with a big malt load, huge hop load, and thick palate.  However, like many black IPAs, the components here dont seem to meld as well as they should.  Still, a very good beer, and a nice addition to the anniversary series.

Additional text and re-rate of 2nd bomber 15-Oct-2011.  Had this again, and I still like the nose, but holistically this one gets almost too bitter, charred malty, and resiny hoppy at the end, with a huge bitter coffee flavor.  It pours and smells very good, but the palate and flavor lose it halfway through.  Not bad, but not something Id drink again.

Bottle. Deep opaque brown-black body, medium light brown head with obscene lacing. Nose of charred, piny hops and dark chocolate. Bitter, pungent body, with big alcohol notes bordering on Band-aids, charcoal, and soy, also some sweet plummy dark fruit notes that attempt to ease the brutality of the hops. Oily and leathery. Coarse, aggressive, and difficult to enjoy.
A black IPA.  Wonderful idea!  This combination of an imperial IPA and an imperial Stout works well.  Just be sure to let it warm a bit; at 8 bucks a bomber you want to taste it fully.

Bottle (22oz) shared with friends. Pours a very dark brown, almost black, with an average size frothy light-brown head -- slightly oily looking. Lovely aroma of roasted malt, good amount of leafy hops, some coffee, chocolate, a bit of cream and molasses. Flavour, also nice, of  roasted malt, lots of leafy hops, some alcohol, coffee & chocolate. Big bitter finish. Alcohol is there but not as much as the abv suggests. Medium bodied. Great stuff, I loved it.

Pour black with nice brown head good lace. Aroma chocolate, coffee, roast, citrus, stone fruits, blueberry, tropical fruits. Taste molasses, licorice, roast, coffee, burnt sugar, supppper bitter, grapefruit, pine, citrus, resiny hops. MF full body creamy rich long super bitter lingering beast with excellent carb. Overall excellent offering very well brewed and a truly unique beer I would expect no less. Cheers to 15 years!

7/10/2011 on tap @ Blind Tiger, NYC (2011-548) 
Very dark brown to black beer, creamy small beige head, bit stable and adhesive. Aroma: exotic fruits, passion and pineapple, sweet lime sorbet. MF: good carbon, full body. Taste: very fruity, citrus, grapefruits, sour pineapple, bitter piny hops. Aftertaste: very dry long lasting bitter ending, mocha and coffee only in the end.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2011 Pours beautiful black with thick white head.  Clings to the glass with sticky lace.  Nose is sweet with raisin and honey.  Smooth and heavy with blast of molasses, cinnamon, and brown sugar.  Ripe grape and spicy burn to finish.  Great beer.

On tap at Dutchs. Black IPAs can be very hit or miss but this one from Stone is certainly one of the better examples out there at the moment. Appearance is opaque black, almost as dark as a stout. Smells like one might expect with a significant hop profile and moderate roasted malts. The taste is like a very smooth but very hoppy stout with the best of both worlds. Easy to drink but complex. Alcohol is well balanced. Overall another fine anniversary offering from Stone.

Bottle.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, brown, mostly lasting.
Body is opaque black (flashlight tested).

Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (roasted grain, dark chocolate), lightly to moderately hoppy (resin, grapefruit), lightly yeasty (dough), with a note of alcohol.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, moderately to heavily acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, moderately to heavily acidic, moderately to heavily bitter, unclean.

Medium to full body, velvety/creamy texture, lively/soft carbonation, moderately to heavily alcoholic, lightly astringent.

Truly disappointing, mainly because it looked so good to begin with.  Nice dark lasting head and completely opaque too.  And the mouthfeel is pretty nice as well...a bit hot/boozy but not out of line given the ABV.  But thats pretty much where the good stuff ends.  The aroma is surprisingly simple and light for a 10+% stout, just roast and chocolate and green hops...theres no allure here, no depth, just some basic expected characters that lay there in the glass with no enthusiasm to entice you in any way.  Heck, theres not even any vanilla, which is usually a freebie with a beer like this.  The worst part, though, is the almost shocking sourness in the mouth...highly unpleasant.  If the mouth experience werent so off-putting, I could probably forgive the boredom of the nose and give this a low/mid-3 kinda score, but alas, something went wrong with this one.

Draft at WOB (Land O Lakes).  Pours an opaque black color with a thin tan head.  Nice lacing along the side of the glass.  Aroma of pine, resin and hops.  Flavor has a ton of hop bitterness up front with some roasted malt and coffee notes and the aftertaste.  The 10.5% is surprisingly well masked.  Very nice. Happy Anniversary Stone!

Just a retarded idea imo to have a black ipa as your 15th anniversary brew. I bought this cause I found it for 6 bucks which isnt a bad deal on a brew of this "rarity" i guess.

It pours a nice color, a thick, inky blackish brown with a creamy tan head that leaves a thick coating of lacing.

It smells like a package of the tropical starburst mixed with tootsie rolls. Some might like it but i think it reeks of a poorly thought out recipe.

The flavor is really well, all over the place. There is some coffee notes, some indecipherable hop notes, odd sweetness, moderate bitterness.

This beer is just a mish mash of junk really. Re-do you recipe and actually think before you brew.

Bottle to snifter. Pours dark brown/black with a tan foamy tight head that slowly fades with a lacing. Aroma is roasted malt , alcohol and funky hops almost like dirty feet and some licorice. Taste is pretty awesome rich bitter chocolate and roasty malt with piny grapefruit and herbal flavors some licorice and burnt coffee too. Palate is full and rich with a chaulky dry finish. Very complex black IPA, and the alcohol is well hidden with the abundence of bitter hops.

Opaque black color with a small, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of roasted malts, dark chocolate, dark fruits, floral hops, citrus, pine, and alcohol.  Taste of dark chocolate, roasted malts, pine, tobacco, smoke, citrus, grapefruit and alcohol.
Fresh 22 oz bottle purchase at the brewery. The aroma is of hops.  The tast is of chocolate and coffee bu is overpowered by grapefruity hops. Extreme bitterness ruins what coul have been a good beer.

Fresh 22 oz bottle. Pours a nearly pitch black color, pretty much opaque, and topped by a thick, smooth head of dark tan colored foam that slowly settles to a thin film. Thick rings of lace coat the entire glass nicely. This definitely looks the part. The aroma is extremely hopped up as you would expect with ample amounts of orange and bitter grapefruit hops along with hints of green grass and pine resin. The malt backbone is hefty as well showing dark bittersweet chocolate, fudge brownie, and dark toasted caramel. There is a just a hint of sweet espresso in there as well. The flavor follows and shows ample amounts of dark, bitter sweet chocolate, roast, toasted caramel, and plenty of citrus hop bitterness on the backend. The chocolate fudge brownie, roast, and biting hops come together and balance things out nicely while not letting things get overly sweet. The body is medium-full and smooth with moderate carbonation that leads to a dry, roasty, and bitter finish. Really nice take on the black ipa style with using more of the citrus hops and oils. Great beer that is easily one of my favorites from Stone.

[3891-20110819] Tap. Mild celery grain aroma. Dark brown black body with a quick foamy off-white head. Toasted grainy flavour has a lingering burnt note. Medium-full body. Tasty. (7/3/7/3/13) 3.3
(@ Coles, Buffalo, NY)

Black, good off-white head.  Flowery hop aroma with some roasted coffee behind it.  Taste is tons of bitter coffee and chocolate but mixed interestingly with hops bitterness.  Theres a good, light palate with some almost fruit flavors.  The finish doesnt have much bitterness, but does have a decent amount of coffee.

Bottle from my mommy.  Dark pour with a brown head.  Aroma is mostly pine with a little fruit and roast.  Taste is lots of roast, bitter, pine, and a citrus/coffee finish.  Finish is somehow enjoyable, yet confusing.

Location: 22 oz bottle from Sparrow, 10/9/11


Aroma: The nose is fairly hoppy, it has some resin, pine, and some roasted malts too

Appearance: This one pours a dark brown color with a small light brown head, and light lace

Flavor: The taste is light-mid sweet, and mid-plus bitter, with mostly roast and pine/resin flavors

Palate: The body is medium-full, the mouthfeel is slightly sticky, and there is just a drop of heat present

Overall Impression: 
This was a pretty interesting offering for sure.  This is another nice job by Stone at making a hoppy beer, which is no surprise, since these guys know hops.  I really enjoyed this one.  The only complaint I have is there is just a touch too much sticky sweetness on the mouthfeel, but that is quite a minor complaint, as I really enjoyed this beer overall.

What a description, RB should have limits on the length of the description. On tap at the vintage estate and listed simply as stones double black ipa.  Big and black fronm the tap with thicjk choco moose head that fades rapidly.  Smells like pine tar. No cos in this bitter dregg. Roasty bitter nand rude, not much here for a lager lover. Mouth coating flat soapy over all finsh.  Being on tap is the only thing that saved this brew. werw
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: A pitch black appearance with a tan head. The aroma contains coffee, chocolate, caramel, and a bit of citrus. The flavor is more on the stout side than the IPA side containing some chocolate, coffee, caramel, and a bit of lemons and oranges. Some alcohol showing in the finish.  Im usually not a fan of this style but Stone seems to pull it off better than most.

Bomber.  Very Black with foamy tan head.  BIG bouquet of Northwest hop aromas.  Powerful flavors of bitter black malts along with big bitterness and hops, which actually balance out quit well, mixed in with a brown sugar like sweentness.  Burn in the finish.  Amazing big beer.

Pours very dark and dense with a large coffee colored head.  Aroma of hops,  citrus and grass.  Flavor is malty, sweet carmel and hops.  There is some good hop flavor but it isnt quite strong enough to cut the sweetness completely.  A little bit of alcohol can be tasted.  This beer has a lot of flavor.

Pours deep rich brown from bomber 22 oz bottle with a very dense full head of small mocha bubbles.  Nose is rich tangy bitters of hops with just a hint of molasses.  First sip is tangy hops, but the complex taste middles into sweet malt fullness and finishes with awesomely delicious bitters.  Mouthfeel is just a bit sharp on the tongue but full through the body of the liquid.  Very awesome beer.
Bomber. A full bodied India Dark Ale. Sweet and citrus throughout dominated by a strong bitterness. A slight alcohol burn at the end. Not as heavy as I thought it would be, smooth and easy to drink.

Bomber. Pours a very dark brown almost black with a small creamy light tan head leaving sticky lacing along the glass. The aroma is a strong floral hop with pine and hemp. Medium mouthfeel with a bitter roast and dark chocolate flavor. Alcohol present with a lingering bitter finish. A very impressive black IPA from Stone.
22 oz bottle.  Pours pitch black, looks like a stout.  Smell is sharp, not really sure of what, though.  Taste is certainly hoppy.  Not too bad overall, nothing crazy awesome though.
Strong hop aroma, reminiscent of many other stone brews. Stout-like head. Strong on the hops, almost creamy mouth feel with a clean finish. Good strong brew
Pitch black with a thin dense head. Great nose and a massive hop attack. Very nice clean finish. Yumm!

Pours black with tan head. Nice lacing. Aroma of grapefruit, pine with a little roast. Taste is of sticky hops, sweet, grapefruit, with a subtle roastiness. Light notes of chocolate in the finish. Very nice.

Bottle. Blackish beer with a brown head. Grapefruit and pine aroma. Grapefruit and chocolate flavor with light roast and pine. Medium bodied. Nice bitterness. Grapefruit and pine lingers with chocolate and light roast.

This poured an almost jet black with a darker beige head. Aroma was dark roasted malt, and bitter/herbal hops. Flavor was a tongue bitter between the bitterness of the roast and the bitter herbal and citrus hops. Pretty nice but really not different than the self righteous besides the abv.

@ Stone fest , Chez moeder lambic 
Head: dark brown, creamy 
Colour: black 
Smell: hops, candy, sweet, smokey, bitter, coffee anise ( a bit ) 
Taste: start is very veyr bitter, coffee, hops, black chocolat, boozy, herbs, hops x3 , end is dry , very bitter, herby and earthy anise

On draft at issacs.

Dark brown with reddish hue. A fresh floral hop aroma with a splash of yeast and chocolate.


Flavors of hop, roast, earth and grapefruit. I love it!

Black.  A surprising cascade of medium brown head, 2-inches thick and creamy.  This is surprising.  Normally for this style, brewers use a minimal amount of black malt and roasted barley to achieve the color thereby not obscuring the malt prominence; Stone apparently has other masterful designs in mind.  Aroma is sap, bark, pine, moss, and burnt marshmallow.  Body is medium-thick, slightly syrupy.  Flavor is a light syrupy sweetness up from with bitter Christmas tree resin following, Bark, Charred malt, hints of burnt nuts.  Very bitter, lingering.  Very good, still not quite the best BIPA Ive had or the best offering from Stone.

Bottle. Pour is thick and dark with a very decent head. Aromas are fairly understated. A little bit of chocolate and dark fruit are about all I pick up in the nose. Maybe a whiff of herbal hops here and there, but that seems generous and maybe a little bit of my imagination is expressing itself. Flavor is a pleasant mix of bitter coffee grounds, dark chocolate and prune like dark fruit with anise and lots of hops. Perfect balance on the palate after the first scalding sip. Thanks for 15 years, Stone.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Excellent outing from Stone.  Pours black with a dark, tan head.  Strong hops aroma.  Taste is strong hops, but not overpowering.  Bitter, but light aftertaste.  Medium build on the palate. Smooth finish.  One of the best black IPAs out there.  Another great style from Stone

22oz bottle.  Vintage (Aug) 2001.  Very dark pour, thick body, heavy black color, long lasting dark brown foam.  Heavy aroma of fresh, green hops.  Heavily dry hopped. Scent of green hops and alcohol.  Tastes of burnt malt and way too much hops.  Flavor has a heavy resin, deep fresh-cut green grass character.  Long lingering bitterness and very strong.  Dont really know which hit me harder,  the high ABV or the over abundance of bitterness.  Overall, this is simply an Imperial Self Righteous.  Whoa, it is bitter.  



Rating 3115.

This beer pours an (imagine that) black color letting through zero light with a thick cappuccino head.   Aroma is of lovely hops with deep chocolate malts.  Taste is out of this world.  Hops up front followed by a deep dark chocolate finished with sweet american hops.  I feel semi-guilty of a crime for describing this beers flavor in one sentence, however its just three or four notes brewed to perfection.  Fantastic beer Ive already drank on multiple occasions

Steady black with a tan cover.  Aroma is nicely hoppy, kind of spicy mixed with a bit of herbal and roasted malt.  Taste is roughly the same, the astringent malt mixes with the spicy hops and light alcohol to finish with a strong bite.  Drinks light for its ABV.

Longest description of a beer ever.

Bottle.  Pours black with a tan head.  Aroma of caramel, pine hops, touch of citrus.  Fairly sweet with some bitter pine hops in there.  Little bit of roast character.  Well done though.
Deep black color with this beer.  Reddish tint to the brown head.  Medium amount of foamy.  Huge pine needle aroma.  Huge pine needle taste.  Pretty bitter.  Awesome

Poured into a etched glass. Pours jet black, darker tan head, nice lacing. Aroma is perfect for a black ipa.  nice roastiness, and citrus hops. Very clean. Palate has lively carbonation and finishes dry. The dry finish is the only detection of alcohol. I think this black ipa is very well balanced! Another gem from stone!

had this from tap and it poured a good black color with a small and foamy head

nice aromas of coffee, hops, toffee, and caramel. Something lacks a little on the nose though

fuller bodied with a lot of roast coffee and hops. Good feel as well and it doesnt come off as boozy.

this is on the big side without being too big. Nice complexity and good richness to it as well

Too much alcohol  over-powders everything in taste, and especially after-taste! I followed this with a Pilsner Urquell---which still managed to have more "beer" taste. Fruity hops in aroma and initial flavor. Attractive opaque black color and tan, small bubble, head. Little malt influence.

My god, Dasilky is right. What a boozy fuckin mess. The few redeeming qualitys are just overshadowed by the over the top boozyness of this beer. Rough. Bless those of you who enjoyed it. May try again at a later date but i dont think i,ll be able to do it.Nice label.  Bomber from statelineliquors.
22oz  Jet black pour, coating teh glass, nice cocoa head. Nose is citrusy hops. Tastes like a proper ale with some finer roasted notes thrown in.

22oz bottle: Pours an opaque black with a stringy-lacing tan head.  Has a sweet toasty dark caramel malty nose with a fresh resiny piny hop character and a touch of roastiness. Starts with pretty good fullness and sweet sugary dark malts with some juicy hop flavor before a sweet and hoppy finish. A little too sugary, but still pretty true to style.

bottle - Pours black and has a big piney hop aroma with roast malt. The flavor has huge hop bitterness with piney, earthy, and resinous characteristics. The roast malt is there and lends this brew a full body, but everything takes a back seat to the hops. It leads into a bitter, warming finish. I really like it, but not everyone will. This brew has very intense flavors.

22 oz bomber pours a dark black color with a large tan head.  Aromas of citrus, pine, and grass, with some roasted malt in the background.  Medium bodied with the citrus bitterness up front, and coffe/chocolate at the end, with an oily mouthfeel.  Very nice

Pours a viscous black with a thick chocolate milk head. Aroma is insane. I could smell hops as soon as I cracked the cap, before I completely removed it. Very strong citrus and pine notes overlay a mild chocolate and roast base, with a hint of booze. Smells a little like Ruination. Taste is very intense. My mouth hasnt buckled like that since my first sip of Rochefort 8. A wave of smooth, dark chocolate with a touch of roast and coffee. Finishes with a gut punch of pine bitterness. Really toes the line between a black IPA and an incredibly hoppy stout. Palate is thick and very rich, with a trailing slickness. Incredible. Truly an experience in a glass. Kinda boozy, but otherwise perfect.

22oz bomber. Pours black with immense tan head. Aroma is resiny green piney hops with touches of chocolate. Flavor is rich and malty with lots of chocolate and caramel. Lots of hop flavor. Immense chocolatey bitter hop piney finish. Mouthfeel is medium-full bodied with creamy soft head. Overal simply fantastic.  Sublime and surprisingly smooth for such a big beer.

Bottle.  Nearing on black in color with a decent light tan head...wouldve liked more retention.  Windex-like hop aromas at first then a bit of citrus and grass hoppiness, slight bit of roast in the aroma.  Not nearly as bitter as Ive wouldve though from the aroma...hints of cocoa, coffee, grapefruit and resin with a dryish finish. Medium body thats a bit silky and slick with softer carbonation.

Bottle.  Pours a deep black color with a thick, milk chocolate colored head.  Aroma is hoppy with a strong roasted coffee and caramel background.  Delicious - strong, citrus hop flavor melts into an equally strong malty finish.  Caramel, roasted pine, licorice, and coffee notes finish off this phenomenal beer. A reward after a very long night at work. 22oz bomber into a tulip. Super dark brown with a tan head that laced well. Aroma was full pine and orange/grapefruit mix. This leaned more to a DIPA than a porter. taste gave me some orange and alcohol at first, tiny bit malt in the middle then the bitterness rushes in for a long finish.
